results.abstract: Twelfth article in series, How Race is Lived in America, examining race relations, which are being defined less by political action than by daily experience, especially in workplace; focuses on racial boundaries within hip-hop culture of black entertainers and rap artists, which has been embraced by many whites to slip through bounds of whiteness; photos (L)

headline.main: Guarding the Borders Of the Hip-Hop Nation

results.snippet: He waited until the bus was ready to leave before squeezing up front to address the passengers. The Greyhound was going from Chicago to Indiana. It was winter. The sky was suffused with gray.    He surveyed the bunched rows of seats. There were only...
results.lead_paragraph: He waited until the bus was ready to leave before squeezing up front to address the passengers. The Greyhound was going from Chicago to Indiana. It was winter. The sky was suffused with gray. He surveyed the bunched rows of seats. There were only 19 passengers, most of them young, most of them black. Billy Wimsatt was white. It was an audience that made him especially comfortable.

results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Sailing the Harbor: Alice's Tall Ships,'' photographs by Alice Austin 100 years ago; through Sept. 3. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

results.abstract: Laura Winters article on Canadian director Jeremy Podeswa, who recalls meeting between producer Camelia Frieberg and horticulturalist Larry Burkam, who eventually married; event served as inspiration for his new feature film, The Five Senses, starring Philippe Volter and Pascale Bussieres; photo (M)

headline.main: A Sense of What Brings Us Together

results.snippet: IN the fall of 1994, the Canadian director Jeremy Podeswa and his producer Camelia Frieberg were heading down the West Coast to promote Mr. Podeswa's first film, ''Eclipse.'' They stopped to see a woman whom Ms. Frieberg had met when she was a...
results.lead_paragraph: IN the fall of 1994, the Canadian director Jeremy Podeswa and his producer Camelia Frieberg were heading down the West Coast to promote Mr. Podeswa's first film, ''Eclipse.'' They stopped to see a woman whom Ms. Frieberg had met when she was a teenager on vacation; the two women had agreed, as a lark, to meet again in 20 years' time. During the visit, they met the horticulturalist Larry Burkam, who was working on the woman's property, and they all ended up having dinner. ''And you could just see the lightning bolts over the table,'' Mr. Podeswa recalled recently. ''When we got back to the hotel that night, I looked at Camelia and said, 'You know, I have the funniest feeling that you're going to marry that guy.' ''

results.abstract: Richard Bernstein reviews Tuff by Paul Beatty; photo (M)

headline.main: An Insider Battles the Inner-City Trap

results.snippet: TUFF  By Paul Beatty  259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.     The eponymous Tuff of Paul Beatty's new novel is a smart small-time hoodlum from the streets of East Harlem who sees things as they are and whose dreams that they might be different smash up...
results.lead_paragraph: TUFF By Paul Beatty 259 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23. The eponymous Tuff of Paul Beatty's new novel is a smart small-time hoodlum from the streets of East Harlem who sees things as they are and whose dreams that they might be different smash up against the jagged edges of reality. He is 19, married and the father of a small boy, and he is surrounded by a cast of characters who, like Tuff himself, are outside the usual categories. His best friend is a disabled anti-Semitic black Muslim who is always coming up with get-rich schemes, legal and otherwise. His father is a cant-spouting former Black Panther who begins poetry readings by firing shotgun shells into the auditorium ceiling. His self-appointed mentor is a black rabbi named Spencer Throckmorton, who converted to Judaism to marry his college sweetheart and became a rabbi even though she later left him. Tuff, whose real name is Winston Foshay, decides about midway through Mr. Beatty's satirical ghetto romp to run for city council, raising money by working in a three-card monte scam in midtown Manhattan.

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

results.abstract: Sen John McCain, who has been busy on campaign trail on behalf of host of Congressional candidates since abandoning his presidential race in Mar, plans to lead his old campaign team and some 60 journalists to Republican National Convention; holds wide range of activities he plans for convention are not aimed at overshadowing what he holds is clearly Gov George W Bush's event, interview; Bush's advisers hold McCain's star power will benefit Bush by drawing attention of independent voters (M)

headline.main: Noncandidate McCain Is Still Running Hard

results.snippet: Senator John McCain seems to be working harder at not running for president than some guys -- we won't mention names -- do in actually campaigning for the job.    Since abandoning the race for the Republican nomination in March, he has campaigned in...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain seems to be working harder at not running for president than some guys -- we won't mention names -- do in actually campaigning for the job. Since abandoning the race for the Republican nomination in March, he has campaigned in so many states, for so many Congressional candidates and raised so much money, that his aides have lost track of all three.

results.abstract: Ann Powers reviews concert by bands Grandaddy, Home and Bright Eyes at Bowery Ballroom; photo (M)

headline.main: Offspring of the Imagination, Nurtured and Set Aloft

results.snippet: Along the one-lane roads of America, you can sometimes spot a depository of the imagination. Giant insects sculptured from scrap metal, apocalyptic visions painted on fence slats, a flower bed in the shape of a heart: these things become folk art...
results.lead_paragraph: Along the one-lane roads of America, you can sometimes spot a depository of the imagination. Giant insects sculptured from scrap metal, apocalyptic visions painted on fence slats, a flower bed in the shape of a heart: these things become folk art when documented, but in their own backyards they're magically animate. This home-birthed art has its equivalents in rock, including a recent style influenced by Pavement, the band out of Stockton, Calif. Literary and homespun, dilapidated and grand, it allows outsider auteurs to present epics on a foundation of bent guitar chords. Grandaddy, Home and Bright Eyes, leading lights of this backyard school, played on Friday night at the Bowery Ballroom. Grandaddy blithely acknowledged its debt with a Pavement cover halfway through its set, but this band, from Modesto, Calif., benefited equally from other preoccupations. Jason Lytle, Grandaddy's mastermind, stood behind a bank of seemingly broken-down vintage keyboards with a guitar decorated with taped-on foliage around his neck. He looked like a mad scientist of the forest, making music in a dusky space where the organic meets the digital.
